question: Ic (beon) #### hal — I will be safe
explanation: Here 'beon' is in the first person singular form 'beo' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Ðu ana (beon) #### eallra dema — You alone are the judge of all
explanation: Here 'beon' is in the second person singular form 'bist' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Min sweord (beon) #### min lif — My sword is my life
explanation: Here 'beon' is in the third person singular form 'biþ' as the subject is 'min sweord'

question: Swa manige (beon) #### men ofer eorþan, swa beoþ modgeþoncas — There are as many viewpoints as there are men on earth
explanation: Here 'beon' is plural form 'beoþ' as the subject is 'men

question: Ic ondræde me for ðam ðe ic (wesan) #### nacod — I am afraid because I am naked
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the first person singular form 'eom' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Sarnys ðe hrepode ond ðu (wesan) #### geunrotsod — Pain touched you and you are made unhappy
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the second person singular form 'eart' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Þearle (wesan) #### me nu min heorte onhæted ond hige geomor swyðe mid sorgum gedrefed — Now my heart is in me sorely inflamed and my mind troubled, deeply afflicted with sorrows
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the third person singular form 'is' as the subject is 'min heorte'

question: (wesan) #### þissa heldora wegas forworhte — These gates of hell are obstructed
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the pluralform 'sind' as the subject is 'þissa heldora wegas'

question: Hiericho seo burh (wesan) #### mid weallum ymbtrymed ond fæste belocen — Jericho, the city, was surrounded with walls and firmly locked
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past third person singular form 'wæs' as the subject is 'seo burh'

question: Forðan ðe ðu (wesan) #### gehyrsum ðines wifes wordum, and min bebod forsawe, þu scealt mid earfoðnyssum þe metes tilian — Because you were obedient to the words of your wife, and despised my commandment, you shall get your food with hardships
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past second person singular form 'wære' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Drihten (wesan) #### sprecende on sumere tide to his apostolum mid bigspellum — The Lord was speaking at a certain time to his apostles in parables
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past third person singular form 'wæs' as the subject is 'Drihten'

question: Hie (wesan) #### gesamnode binnan ðære byrig Hierusalem, six hund ðusend manna — They were assembled within the city of Jerusalem, six hundred thousand men
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past plural form 'wæron' as the subject is 'hie'

question: Ðær ic (beon) #### fægere beþeaht fiðerum ðinum — There I will be pleasantly enveloped in your wings
explanation: Here 'beon' is in the first person singular form 'beo' as the subjet is 'ic'

question: For ðan ðe ðu ðis dydest, ðu (beon) #### awyrged betweox eallum nytenum and wildeorum — Because you did this, you will be cursed among all the beasts and wild animals
explanation: Here 'beon' is in the second person singular form 'beo' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Hat (beon) #### monegum egeslic æled — The dreadful fire will be hot to many
explanation: Here 'beon' is in the third person singular form 'biþ' as the subject is 'æled'

question: Swa biþ sæ smilte þonne hie wind ne weceþ, swa (beon) #### þeoda geþwære, þonne hie geþingad habbað — As the sea is calm when the wind doesn't blow, so are people at peace when they have negotiated
explanation: Here 'beon' is in the plural form 'beoþ' as the subject is 'þeoda'

question: Ic (wesan) #### mare þonne þes middangeard, læsse þonne hondwyrm, leohtre þonne mona, swiftre þonne sunne — I am more than this middle world, less than a mite, lighter than the moon, swifter than the sun
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the first person singular form 'eom' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Nu (wesan) #### þu dumb ond deaf — Now you are dumb and deaf
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the second person singular form 'eart' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Her (wesan) #### seo bot hu þu meaht þine æ ceras betan gif hie nellaþ wel weaxan — Here is the remedy how you can restore your fields if they will not grow well
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the third person singular form 'is' as the subject is 'seo bot'

question: Hie cwædon 'Drihten her (wesan) #### twa swurd' — They said, 'Lord, here are two swords'
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the plural form 'sind' as the subject is 'twa swurd'

question: Se Cristendom (wesan) #### swilc on his dæge þæt ælc man hwæt his hade to belumpe folgade se þe wolde — Christianity in his day was such that every man who wanted to would follow what pertained to his order
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past third person singular form 'wæs' as the subject is 'se Cristendom'

question: Paulus cwæð to Petre: Broðer þu (wesan) #### Gode gecoren ær ic — Paul said to Peter, 'Brother, you were God's chosen before me'
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past second person singular form 'wære' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Freond he (wesan) #### ðurh geleafan ond wiþercora þurh weorc — A friend he was through faith, and a reprobate in works
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past third person singular form 'wæs' as the subject is 'he'

question: Hie (wesan) #### swa eaþmode ond swa unscæððige swa þæt cild wæs — They were as humble and as innocent as that child was
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the past plural form 'wæron' as the subject is 'hie'

question: Ic (gan) #### ut on dægræde þywende oxan to felda — I go out at dawn driving oxen to fields
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the first person singular form 'ga' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Ðu (gan) #### beforan Drihtnes ansyne his wegas gearwian — You go before the face of the Lord to prepare His ways
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the second person singular form 'gæst' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Ver is lengtentima ond he (gan) #### to tune on .vii. idus Februarii — Fair is Spring and he goes to town on 7 to the ides of February
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the third person singular form 'gæþ' as the subject is 'he'

question: He ða gesceop of ðære eorðan eall nytencynn, and deorcynn, ealle ða ðe on feower fotum (gan) #### — He then created of earth all the race of cattle, and the brute race, all those which go on four feet
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the plural form 'gaþ' as the subject is 'ealle ða ðe on feower fotum'

question: Ic (gan) #### ða to Godes ðenunge ond ðaet folc gebletsode ond him Godes gerihtu dyde — I went then to God's ministry and blessed the people, and celebrated God's rights before them
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past first person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þa þu geongre wære, þu gertest þe and (gan) #### þær þu woldest — When you were younger, you used to dress yourself and used to go where you wished
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past second person singular form 'eodest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: He (gan) #### ofer sæ mid drygum fotum ond he gestilde windas mid his hæse — He went over the sea with dry feet, and he stilled the winds by his command
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past third person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'he'

question: Hie ða to ðæm symle sittan, (gan) #### wlance to wingedrince, ealle his weagesiðas bealde byrnwiggende — Then they went to sit down to the feast, proud at the wine—drinking, all his woeful companions, bold byrnied warriors
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past plural form 'eodon' as the subject is 'hie'

question: Ic (gan) #### on minne bate ond rowe ut on þa ea ond weorpe min nett on þa ea — I go into my boat, row out on the water, and cast my net into the water
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the first person singular form 'ga' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þu (gan) #### on þinum breoste and etst þa eorðan eallum dagum þines lifes — You go on your breast and eat the earth all the days of your life
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the second person singular form 'gæst' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Þa feng Æscwine to rice, þæs cynes (gan) #### to Cerdice, ond heold .ii. gear — Then Æscwine succeeded to the kingdom, of that descent which goes back to Cerdic, and held it 2 years
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the third person singular form 'gæþ' as the subject is 'þæs cynes'

question: Ne lifað na se man be hlafe anum ac lifað be ðæm wordum ðe (gan) #### of Godes muðe — Man lives not by bread alone, but lives by the words which go from the mouth of God.
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the plural form 'gaþ' as the subject is 'ðæm wordum'

question: Ic (gan) #### fram ðæm fæder ond com in ðisne middangeord efersonað — I went from the father and came in this world again
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past first person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þa cwæð he: 'la freond hu—mæte (gan) #### ðu in' — Then he said, 'Lo! Friend, in what manner went you in?'
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past second person singular form 'eodest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: He (gan) #### cwicu and gesund into his byrgene — He went quick and whole into his grave
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past second person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'he'

question: Þine syll (gan) #### ond ða assan wið hie læswodon; þa færlice comon Sabei ond hie ealle us benamon and ðine yrðlingas ofslogon — Your ploughs went and the asses grazed near; then suddenly Sabaeans came, and they took all of us and killed your plowman
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past plural form 'eodon' as the subject is 'Þine syll'

question: Ond ic (don) #### eall swa ge biddaþ — And I will do all as you ask
explanation: Here 'don' is in the first person singular form 'do' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwæt (don) #### þu gif unclæne fiscas beoþ? — What do you do if it is unclean fish?
explanation: Here 'don' is in the second person singular form 'dest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Gif esne (don) #### his rade þaes daeges, .vi. se wiþ dryhten gebete oþþe sine hyd — If a servant makes a journey of his own on that day, he shall pay 6 shillings compensation to his lord or undergo the lash
explanation: Here 'don' is in the third person singular form 'deþ' as the subject is 'esne'

question: Ne winne ge ongen ða ðe eow yfel (don) #### — Strive ye not against those who do you wrong
explanation: Here 'don' is in the plural form 'doþ' as the subject is 'ða ðe'

question: On þisse nihte manega þingc ic (don) #### — I did many things on this night
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past first person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þu, cnapa, hwæt (don) #### todæg? — You, boy, what did you do today?
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past second person singular form 'dydest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Ða behydde Adam hine ond his wif eac swa (don) #### — Then Adam hid himself and his wife also did so
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past third person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'his wif'

question: Hu ne forealdodon þa gewritu þeah ond losodon, swa some swa þa writeras (don) #### — Would not the writings nevertheless get old and perish, just as the writers did
explanation: Here 'don' is in the plural form 'dydon' as the subject is 'þa writeras'

question: Ic melke hie tweowa on dæge þærto ge cyse ge buteran ic (don) #### ond ic eom getrywe hlaforde minum — I milk them twice a day, then I do the cheese and the butter, and I am faithful to my lord
explanation: Here 'don' is in the first person singular form 'do' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwæt (don) #### þu be þinre huntunge? — What do you do about your catch?
explanation: Here 'don' is in the second person singular form 'dest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Ða se hehsta Dema ædre mid elne onbryrde swa he (don) #### anra gehwylcne herbuendra þe hyne him to helpe seceð — Then the highest judge swiftly inspired her with courage, as He does each person who seeks His help
explanation: Here 'don' is in the third person singular form 'deþ' as the subject is 'he'

question: Ðæt cild weox swa swa oðre cild (don) #### — The child grew as other children do
explanation: Here 'don' is in the plural form 'doþ' as the subject is 'oðre cild'

question: Cumað ond geseoð ðone man ðe me sæde ealle ða ðing ic (don) #### — Come and see the man who said to me all the things I did
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past first person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: God cwæð to ðam wife: Hwi (don) #### ðu ðæt? Heo cwæð: Seo nædre bepæhte me and ic ætt — God said to the woman, 'why did you do that?' She said, 'the snake deceived me and I ate'
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past second person singular form 'dydest' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: swa he ær on ðæm beame (don) #### — As he did on that tree before
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past third person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'he'

question: Gif we ænige bote gebidan scylan þonne mote we þæs to Gode earnian bet þonne we ær þysan (don) #### — If we shall experience any remedy, then we must deserve that of God better than we have previously done
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past plural form 'dydon' as the subject is 'we'

question: Ic (willan) #### mid flode folc acwellan ond cynna gehwilc cwicra wihta — I intend to kill with a flood the people and every kind of living creature
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the first person singular form 'wille' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwyder (willan) #### ðu ga? — Where do you intend to go?
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the second person singular form 'wilt' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Se biscop sceal þe (willan) #### onfon Godes mildheortnesse þrafian þa mæssepreostas mid lufe ond mid laþe þæt hie healdan Godes æwe on riht — The bishop that wants to obtain God's mercy, must compel the priests with love and with fear to correctly preserve God’s law
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the third person singular form 'wile' as the subject is 'se biscop'

question: Þry dagas to lafe sindon þæt hie þe (willan) #### acwellan — Three days remain before the day comes on which they intend to kill you
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the plural form 'willaþ' as the subject is 'hie'

question: Forðy ic (willan) #### ðætte hie ealneg æt ðære stowe wæren — Therefore I wanted them always to be there at that place
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past first person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Ic geanbidode swiðe wel oð ic wisse hwæt ðu (willan) #### and hu ðu hit understandan woldest — I waited very willingly until I knew what you wanted and how you would understand it
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past second person singular form 'woldest' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: He cwæð ðæt he (willan) #### þæm wife gemyltsian — He said that he wanted to pardon the woman
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past third person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'he'

question: Loð þa eode to his twam aðumum þe (willan) #### wifian on his twam dohtrum — Lot then went to his two sons in law, who intended to marry his two daughters
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past plural form 'woldon' as the subject is 'his twam aðumum'

question: Hwæt (willan) #### ic ðissum wiðersacan geandwyrdan? — What answer will I give to this denial?
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the first person singular form 'wille' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Cwædon him to: Gif þu ne (willan) #### us geðafian in swa æðelicum þinge þe we biddað ne meaht þu in usse mægðe ne ussum gemanan wunian — They said to him: 'If you will not consent to us in so noble a matter, as we ask, you may not dwell in our country nor in our society'
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the second person singular form 'wilt' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Elpendes hyd (willan) #### drincan wætan, gelice spynge deð — An elephant’s hide will absorb liquid, like a sponge does
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the third person singular form 'wile' as the subject is 'Elpendes hyd'

question: Þonne þy ilcan dæge þe hie hine to þæm ade beran (willan) #### todælað hie his feoh — Then on the same day when they intend to bear him to the pyre, they divide his wealth
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the plural form 'willaþ' as the subject is 'hie'

question: He nyste hwæt ic (willan) #### — He didn't know what I wanted
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past first person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwi (willan) #### þu beswican þæt mære wif Melantian mid forligre? — Why would you entice that excellent woman Melantian with fornication?
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past second person singular form 'woldest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Þa Darius geseah þæt he ouerwunnen beon wolde, þa (willan) #### he hiene selfne on ðæm gefeohte forspillan — When Darius saw that he would be overrun, then he wanted to kill himself on the battlefield
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past third person singular form 'wolde' as the subject is 'he'

question: Ond wið þæm þa ðe in oðre wisan don (willan) #### he wæs mid welme micelre ellenwodnisse onbærned — And against those who wanted to do otherwise he was inspired with great fervor and zeal
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the past plural form 'woldon' as the subject is 'þæm'
